intro: Eschscholzia parishii, commonly known as the Parish's poppy, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Papaveraceae family, which includes other well-known poppies. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils and is found in arid and semi-arid regions. It produces striking red or orange flowers that bloom in the spring. Its botanical features include lobed leaves and a capsule-like fruit that contains the seeds.
